explanation: Agent A’s scenario points out a plausible out‑of‑bounds read, but the provided code alone does not prove a MISRA Rule 21.17 violation. The function shown (MHD_str_to_uint64_n_) itself does not call any <string.h> routines and therefore cannot by itself violate Rule 21.17. The reported problem concerns the interaction between MHD_lookup_connection_value_n (called with a pointer-only return) and MHD_str_equal_caseless_ (which may call NUL-terminated string routines). Whether a real violation exists depends on the documented/actual behaviour of those two functions: if MHD_lookup_connection_value_n guarantees to return a NUL‑terminated buffer when the caller requests only a pointer (i.e. when the length parameter is NULL), or if MHD_str_equal_caseless_ is implemented to respect an explicit length or to avoid library string functions that scan to a NUL, then there is no violation. If neither guarantee holds (lookup may return a non‑NUL‑terminated slice and the comparator uses strcmp/strcasecmp), then the code can read past the header buffer and would violate Rule 21.17. In short: the report identifies a valid potential violation, but with the code snippets given there is insufficient evidence to conclude an actual MISRA Rule 21.17 violation — you must inspect the implementations/contracts of MHD_lookup_connection_value_n and MHD_str_equal_caseless_.
